channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Militants Destroy Tomb of 13th-Century Scholar
item.description: Militants of the Nusra Front, who have links to Al Qaeda, have blown up the 13th-century tomb of a revered Islamic scholar in southern Syria, according to Syria’s state news agency.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Suicide Attacks Leave at Least 23 People Dead
item.description: Suicide attacks against security checkpoints and Shiite worshipers killed at least 23 people in Iraq on Thursday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Monterrey Journal: A Bus Takes a Local Route to Fighting Mexican Corruption
item.description: Born through a mix of frustration, satire and savvy, the Corruptour is a free one-hour ride led by young activists hoping to stir a political awakening with five trips per weekend.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:credit: Rodrigo Cruz for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Corruptour bus, which visits sites linked to corruption in Monterrey, Mexico, is decorated with caricatures of politicians.

item.title: Cuba Is Reported to Release 26 Dissidents
item.description: Some of the prisoners were believed to be among 53 that Cuba had agreed to free last month as part of a thaw with the United States.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Arabia: U.S. Seeks to Halt a Blogger’s Lashing
item.description: The United States asked the Saudi authorities on Thursday to cancel a sentence of 1,000 lashes given to a liberal blogger.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Peru: Jailed Ex-President Is Convicted of Corruption
item.description: Former President Alberto Fujimori on Thursday was convicted of using public money to influence newspaper coverage during his 2000 re-election campaign.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: Tribunal Resumes Genocide Hearings
item.description: A tribunal restarted genocide hearings on Thursday against the Khmer Rouge’s most senior surviving leaders, with the first witness being called to testify against them.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Addis Ababa Memo: A Moment of Optimism on Sudan Peace Fades as New Talks Approach
item.description: Peace talks that ended in December failed to produce an agreement and prompted analysts to question whether the divided government can, or even wants to, reach a deal.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Early Returns Show a New President for Sri Lanka
item.description: Sri Lanka’s longtime president, Mahinda Rajapaksa, conceded after he unexpectedly lost his bid for re-election to a former health minister Maithripala Sirisena.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and DHARISHA BASTIANS
item.media:description: Backers of President Mahinda Rajapaksa, who was trailing a former ally, Maithripala Sirisena.

item.title: Police Hunt for Suspects in Paris Attack as Nation Mourns
item.description: As French citizens mourned their dead, the authorities were carrying out an intense search for the brothers suspected of attacking a Paris newspaper.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:credit: Francois Xavier Marit/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Journalists at Agence France-Presse in Paris held signs Thursday reading “Je suis Charlie” (I am Charlie) during a moment of silence for the victims of the attack at the newspaper Charlie Hebdo.

item.title: Al Qaeda Trained Suspect in Paris Terror Attack, Official Says
item.description: The suspect, Saïd Kouachi, 34, is said to have spent “a few months” training in small arms combat, marksmanship and other skills.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Francois Lo Presti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Members of the French police special forces on a search for two terrorism suspects in Corcy, in northern France, on Thursday.

item.title: From Sergeant-at-Arms to Canadian Ambassador
item.description: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Common, rose from relative obscurity when his role in ending an attack on parliament was learned.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Adrian Wyld/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kevin Vickers, the sergeant-at-arms of Canada’s House of Commons who killed a gunman after he stormed Parliament last year, was named Ambassador to Ireland.

item.title: U.S. Consolidates Forces in Europe to Save Money
item.description: Defense officials said that more American troops would be stationed in Germany and Italy as the United States sought to counter a more aggressive Russia.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: Egypt Moves to Eradicate Town Near Gaza Strip
item.description: Egypt began evacuating hundreds of families from Rafah on Thursday after a senior official acknowledged that the military was eliminating the town to complete a security zone.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: News: Updates on Search for Suspects
item.description: As the manhunt continued, France extended its highest level terror alert to Picardy, a region north of greater Paris.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: North Korea Seems to Be Closer to Missile-Launching Submarine
item.description: A research group that focuses on North Korea said satellite imagery showed what appeared to be launching tubes on a North Korean submarine.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Passengers’ Accounts of Rescue From Burning Ferry Differ Sharply
item.description: One passenger rescued in waters off Greece last week told of “chaos.” Another said “everything worked.”
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Before Paris Shooting, Authors Tapped Into Mood of a France ‘Homesick at Home’
item.description: A futuristic novel and a nostalgic essay had set off intense debate even before the attack on Charlie Hebdo.
item.dc:creator: By RACHEL DONADIO
item.media:description: In his novel “Submission,” Michel Houellebecq imagines France in 2022, with a Muslim president.

item.title: Letter From Europe: No Safety for Christians in the Mideast
item.description: For decades, Christian communities in the Middle East have dwindled, and an acceleration of this trend is fundamentally rewriting the region's demography.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Recounting a Bustling Office, Then a ‘Vision of Horror’ at Charlie Hebdo
item.description: As witnesses recounted the massacre at the French satirical newspaper, details emerged of a routine day turned violent.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: The actress Lou Douillon held aloft a candle a vigil for the Paris shooting victims in Place de la République on Thursday.
